titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the Ray Yoshida Papers, 1903-2010, bulk 1950-2005, in the Archives of American Art AAA.yoshray
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 360857

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-05-05T08:55-0400

did.langmaterial: Collection is in English and Japanese.
did.abstract: The papers of Chicago artist and educator Ray Yoshida measure 9.1 linear feet and date from 1903 to 2010, with the bulk of the material dating from 1950 to 2005. Yoshida’s career as a painter and collagist as well as his long tenure as a professor at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago are documented through biographical material, personal correspondence, notebooks and writings, teaching records, personal business records, printed material, photographs, sketchbooks, artwork by Yoshida and others, and scrapbooks. Items within the collection also document Yoshida’s personal interest in collecting folk art and artifacts.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The collection was donated in 2012 by Ray Yoshida via Terri Yoho of the Kohler Foundation, representing Yoshida's estate, and in 2013 by Jennifer Sabas and Shayle Miller, estate executors.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington D.C. research facility. Use of archival audiovisual recordings with no duplicate access copy requires advance notice. One box of letters from Jim Nutt are ACCESS RESTRICTED; use requires written permission.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Ray Yoshida papers, 1903-2010, bulk 1950-2005. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The Ray Yoshida papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: The collection was processed to a minimal level and a finding aid prepared by Erin Kinhart in 2015. The collection has been minimally rearranged and retains the existing/original folder titles when possible. All materials have been rehoused in archival folders and boxes for long-term stability, but not all staples and other fasteners have been removed. Materials within folders have not been rearranged.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged as 11 series.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, 1950-2005 (0.5 Linear feet; Box 1)
Series 3: Notebooks, circa 1960s-1990s (0.5 Linear feet; Box 3)
Series 4: Writings, circa 1950-2001 (0.4 Linear feet; Boxes 3-4)
Series 5: Teaching Records, 1962-2003 (0.4 Linear feet; Box 4)
Series 6: Personal Business Records, circa 1971-2010 (0.6 Linear feet; Boxes 4-5)
Series 7: Printed Material, circa 1912-2005 (1.9 Linear feet; Boxes 5-6, 12)
Series 8: Photographs, circa 1911-1990s (0.4 Linear feet; Box 7)
Series 9: Sketchbooks, circa 1960s-2000s (0.9 Linear feet; Boxes 7, 10-11)
Series 11: Scrapbooks, early 1900s-1960s (0.6 Linear feet; Boxes 8-11)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Ray Yoshida (1930-2009) was a painter, collagist, and educator in Chicago, Illinois.

Raymond Kakuo Yoshida was born in Kapaa, Hawaii, in 1930. He attended the University of Hawaii for two years and completed a B.A. in Arts Education at the Art Institute of Chicago in 1953. He also served in the U.S. Army for two years during the Korean War. In 1957 he recieved his M.F.A from Syracuse University and became a faculty member at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago in 1959. He was named Frank Harold Sellers Professor in the Department of Painting and Drawing in 1971, retired as professor emeritus in 1998, and continued to teach until 2003.

Yoshida's paintings and collages were strongly influenced by comics as well as his own collection of folk and outsider art. He regularly exhibited at Phyllis Kind Gallery in Chicago from 1975 to 1996, and a major retrospective of his work was organized by the Contemporary Museum of Honolulu in 1998. He retired to Hawaii in 2005 where he lived until his death in 2009.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Chicago artist and educator Ray Yoshida measure 9.1 linear feet and date from 1903 to 2010, with the bulk of the material dating from 1950 to 2005. Yoshida’s career as a painter and collagist as well as his long tenure as a professor at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago are documented through biographical material, personal correspondence, notebooks and writings, teaching records, personal business records, printed material, photographs, sketchbooks, artwork by Yoshida and others, and scrapbooks. Items within the collection also document Yoshida’s personal interest in collecting folk art and artifacts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here is biographical documentation about Ray Yoshida, including award certificates, identification records, student records, and three interview transcripts. Also found is one video recording of a documentary short about Yoshida’s art and object collection at his Chicago home.

did.unittitle: Documentary Short, "The Individuality of the Inanimate Object"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence is primarily of a personal nature and includes numerous letters, postcards, and greeting cards from friends, colleagues, and artists, including Roger Brown, Jim Nutt, Gladys Nilsson, Art Green, Christina Ramberg, Karl Wirsum, Miyoko Ito, Jin Soo Kim, Barbara Rossi, Vera Berdich, and Tom Kapsalis among others. Some letters are illustrated.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Correspondence is arranged in chronological order by year. Undated correspondence is unsorted. Access restricted letters from Jim Nutt are arranged in a separate container.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Notebooks contain notes on art history, art technique, Japanese language, travel, and other subjects. Many of the notebooks include sketches and contain loose items such as news clippings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are Ray Yoshida's writings for college courses, fragments of writings on art and other subjects, and notes. Notes consist of lists, ideas, travel plans, and teaching material. Writings by others include essays by Yoshida’s students, draft essays for exhibitions, and poetry by Susan Wheeler.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Teaching records primarily document Yoshida’s tenure as a professor at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago, though a few records of guest professorships at other schools are included. These records are not comprehensive, but include a few course evaluations, employment records, teaching notes, and photocopies of research material. Also found are numerous letters of recommendation he wrote for students. Miscellaneous teaching records are unsorted and include department memos, planning documents, course summaries and curriculum, correspondence, and notes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here is documentation regarding the sale, exhibition, and loan of artwork by Ray Yoshida, including his business dealings with the Phyllis Kind Gallery. Also found are business cards and address lists, a few business receipts, and a National Endowment for the Arts application. Additionally there are several files regarding the estate of artist Roger Brown and the establishment of the Roger Brown Study Center at the School of the Art Institute of Chicago.

did.unittitle: Exhibition, Ray Yoshida Retrospective, Contemporary Museum, Honolulu
Exhibition, Ray Yoshida Retrospective, Madison Art Center
Loan to Minnesota Museum of American Art
National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship Application

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material includes published documentation about Yoshida’s career as an artist as well as items collected by Yoshida as source material or for personal interest. Found here are exhibition catalogs, invitations, and announcements, as well as news clippings, magazines, newsletters and press releases documenting his career. Collected printed material includes postcards, comics and comic books, mail order catalogs, magazines, product labels, and advertisements. Also found are many small clippings from comics collected for collages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 12, Folder 2

did.unittitle: Oversized News Clippings from Box 6, Folders 3-17

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographs depict Ray Yoshida, friends, students, travel, and artwork. Also found are a few photographs of Karl Wirsum’s studio, as well as photographs of various subjects collected by Yoshida. Additionally, there is one photograph album from the early 1910s with photographs depicting a young woman with her friends and family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Sketchbooks include pencil and ink sketches of various subjects. A few also include loose items such as notes and news clippings. Most sketchbooks appear to contain sketches by Yoshida, but researchers should note that it is possible that some sketchbooks belonged to students or other artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork by Ray Yoshida includes collages on paper, pencil sketches, and ink drawings. Artworks by others include numerous prints by Kathleen Blackshear, Ethel Spears, and Vivian Mayers, and collages, drawings, and prints given to Yoshida by students and friends. Other artwork appears to have been created by children, including handmade picture books, alphabet books, and paper collages. A few items such as hand-painted photographs and painted puzzle pieces were made by an unidentified artist, possibly Yoshida.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 12, Folder 3

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 12, Folder 4

did.unittitle: Artwork by Kathleen Blackshear, Ethel Spears, and Vivian Mayers
Oversized Comic Collages by Ray Yoshida from Box 7, Folder 26
Oversized Drawings by Ray Yoshida from Box 7, Folders 27-28

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Found here are six scrapbooks. Three of the scrapbooks containing source images, clippings, and comics appear to have been created by Yoshida. Three additional scrapbooks were created by others and collected by Yoshida. Included is a child’s scrapbook containing many clippings about the Dionne quintuplets, a scrapbook from the early 1900s containing clippings and ephemera, and a detailed travel scrapbook created by Edward and Edna Hillier.
